title: 107_hr2097
content: The "Child Care Quality Incentive Act of 2001" is the short title of this Act, which aims to improve child care quality. The "Child Care Quality Incentive Act of 2001" aims to improve child care quality by addressing findings on early brain development, the importance of quality early care and education, and the high costs of full-day child care. Only 1 in 7 child care centers promote healthy development, while 1 in 8 threaten safety. Full-day child care costs $4,000 to $10,000 per year. Federal assistance is limited, with many families unable to afford child care. Payment rates are too low to ensure quality care for all families. Low payment rates for child care affect the quality of care children receive, leading to reduced staff, lack of training, and fewer educational activities. This results in delayed development and increased aggression in children. The purpose of this Act is to improve the quality of child care by increasing payment rates, which in turn allows providers to hire qualified staff, provide training, maintain a safe environment, and purchase educational materials. Children in low-quality child care may experience delayed development and increased aggression. Incentive grants are provided to improve the quality of child care. Funding for grants to improve the quality of child care is authorized under the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990. $500,000,000 is appropriated for fiscal year 2002, with additional funds for subsequent years. Appropriated $500,000,000 for fiscal year 2002 and additional funds for subsequent years for grants under the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990. Amendments are made to specify the use of block grant funds and establish the program, excluding section 658H. Amendments to the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 include establishing a program to improve the quality of child care, with the exclusion of section 658H. "Establishing a program to improve the quality of child care through grants." The Secretary will use funds to make grants to eligible States for child care services based on market rates surveys conducted within 2 years. Eligible States must submit an application to receive annual payments. To be eligible for a grant under this section, a State must conduct a market rates survey for child care services within 2 years and submit an application detailing the methodology and results. To be eligible for a grant under this section, a State must conduct a market rates survey for child care services within 2 years and submit an application detailing the methodology, results, and plan to increase payment rates in accordance with the survey results. The State must increase payment rates according to market survey results to maintain eligibility for annual payments under this section. Additionally, the State must update the survey every two years and provide matching funds to receive the grant. To maintain eligibility for annual payments, the State must increase payment rates based on market survey results and update the survey every two years. Additionally, the State must provide matching funds of at least 25% of the costs in cash to receive the grant. State contributions must be in cash and not include Federal Government funds. The amount appropriated under section 658B(b) will be allotted to eligible States based on the same method as section 658O(b). Eligible States receiving a grant must use the funds to increase child care assistance payment rates up to the 100th percentile of the market rate survey. An eligible State receiving a grant under this section must use the funds to increase child care assistance payment rates up to the 100th percentile of the market rate survey. Once achieving this rate, the State can use the funds for activities that enhance the quality of child care services. The 100th percentile of the market rate survey can be used to enhance child care services in the State. Funds received should supplement, not replace, other Federal, State, or local funds. States must submit evaluations on efforts to increase payment rates and their impact on child care quality and accessibility. The State must submit evaluations to the Secretary on efforts to increase payment rates for child care and their impact on quality and accessibility. The Secretary will then submit biennial reports to Congress based on this information. The State must submit evaluations to the Secretary on efforts to increase payment rates for child care. Biennial reports to Congress will be based on this information, including data from applications as a baseline for progress. Amendments are made to define payment rate and specify funding sources. Amendments are made to Section 658O of the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990, including changes to subsections (a), (b), and (e) regarding allotments.
